Literature Review: Electrically controllable materials have been a crucial focus in the development of soft robotic machines, which aim to bridge the performance gap between built and biological systems. The use of soft, actuatable materials has enabled the creation of physically intelligent machines that can adapt and compute through their compliant bodies. However, the selection of materials for physical intelligence often involves low-performance and energy-inefficient stimuli-responsive materials for actuation. This review aims to provide an overview of the progress made in the development of electroprogrammable materials for soft robotic actuation, focusing on thermomechanical, electrostatic, and electrochemical actuation strategies directly controlled by electric currents and fields. The literature review highlights the challenges and opportunities in designing and fabricating next-generation robotic materials that will facilitate true bioinspired autonomy.
